articles.headline: A Fine for Not Using a Biofuel That Doesn’t Exist
articles.snippet: The oil companies could pay $6.8 million in penalties for failing to blend cellulosic biofuel, which is not available commercially, into their diesel and motor fuels.
articles.abstract: The oil companies could pay $6.8 million in penalties for failing to blend cellulosic biofuel, which is not available commercially, into their diesel and motor fuels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the companies that supply motor fuel close the books on 2011, they will pay about $6.8 million in penalties to the Treasury because they failed to mix a special type of biofuel into their gasoline and diesel as required by law.

articles.headline: A Merger Once Scoffed At Bears Fruit in Detroit
articles.snippet: Some analysts said the Chrysler and Fiat merger could become a model for trans-Atlantic cooperation in the auto industry.
articles.abstract: Some analysts said the Chrysler and Fiat merger could become a model for trans-Atlantic cooperation in the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The unlikely union of Chrysler and its Italian parent, Fiat, is beginning to produce new vehicles that combine the talents of both companies.

articles.headline: Wanted or Not: Alternative-Fuel Cars Flood Auto Show
articles.snippet: Automakers are flooding the Detroit auto show with new hybrid and plug-in models, but the combination of gas prices below $4 a gallon and higher upfront costs for the cars is not attracting consumers.
articles.abstract: Automakers are flooding the Detroit auto show with new hybrid and plug-in models, but the combination of gas prices below $4 a gallon and higher upfront costs for the cars is not attracting consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In the race to claim ever-higher fuel-economy numbers and keep up with government regulations, automakers are rolling out hybrids and electric cars aplenty at this week’s Detroit auto show.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Women Find Power Still Hinges on Men
articles.snippet: Despite playing a large role in the protests that ousted President Hosni Mubarak, Egyptian women still face the restrictions of a patriarchal system.
articles.abstract: Despite playing a large role in the protests that ousted President Hosni Mubarak, Egyptian women still face the restrictions of a patriarchal system.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At first Samira Ibrahim was afraid to tell her father that Egyptian soldiers had detained her in Tahrir Square in Cairo, stripped off her clothes, and watched as she was forcibly subjected to a “virginity test.”

articles.headline: A Big Check, and Gingrich Gets a Big Lift
articles.snippet: A $5 million check from Sheldon Adelson underscores how last year’s landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance has made it possible for a wealthy individual to influence an election.
articles.abstract: A $5 million check from Sheldon Adelson underscores how last year’s landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance has made it possible for a wealthy individual to influence an election.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — For weeks this winter, as Newt Gingrich’s presidential hopes faltered under the weight of millions of dollars in attack ads paid for by backers of Mitt Romney, a small group of Gingrich supporters quietly lobbied for help from one of the richest men in America: Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner and Mr. Gingrich’s longtime friend and patron.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Daley Stepping Down in Rare White House Shake-Up
articles.snippet: William M. Daley will be replaced by Jacob J. Lew, the budget director and a seasoned Washington insider, jolting the top ranks of President Obama’s administration in an election year.
articles.abstract: William M. Daley will be replaced by Jacob J. Lew, the budget director and a seasoned Washington insider, jolting the top ranks of President Obama’s administration in an election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that the White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, was stepping down, jolting the top ranks of his administration less than a year before he faces a difficult re-election. Mr. Daley will be replaced by Jacob J. Lew, the budget director and a seasoned Washington insider with ties to Capitol Hill.

articles.headline: Fatal Stampede in South Africa Points Up University Crisis
articles.snippet: One woman died and several people were injured in a stampede by students desperate to apply for admission to a public university.
articles.abstract: One woman died and several people were injured in a stampede by students desperate to apply for admission to a public university.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — They lined up well before dawn, some driving from the deep countryside with bags of fluffy blankets and neatly packed sandwiches, to wait for the gates to a new life to open. They hoped for a shot at a coveted spot at one of South Africa’s public universities, and with it a chance to escape the indignity of joblessness that afflicts more than a third of the nation. By morning, the line was more than a mile long.
